title: Manchester Arena bomber's brother denies 22 counts of murder
text:
Hashem Abedi has denied 22 counts of murder over the Manchester Arena bombing

The younger brother of the Manchester Arena suicide bomber today pleaded not guilty to 22 counts of murder and will go on trial in January next year.

Hashem Abedi, 22, was arrested in Libya shortly after his brother Salman blew himself up as thousands of people left an Ariana Grande concert on 22 May 2017.

He was handed over to British police officers and flown to the UK from Tripoli in July of this year.

Abedi stood in the dock at the Old Bailey today wearing a grey fleece with glasses held together by dental floss and blue tack.

He spoke only to confirm his name and enter his not guilty pleas to 22 counts of murder, one of attempted murder, and one of conspiring to cause explosions.

Mr Justice Baker set Abedi's six to eight week trial for 13 January next year, two months later than it was originally planned for, and remanded him in custody.

In the aftermath of the attack there was a nationwide outpouring of grief with families and friends of the victims left devastated.

The attack saw 22 people, including children killed by the improvised explosive device which was carried in a rucksack.

Salman Abedi killed 22 people, including young children, when he blew himself up at the end of an Ariana Grande concert

The attack targeted parents and children leaving a concert. More than 260 were injured

More than 260 were injured with 600 people reporting psychological harm.

Saffie Rose Roussos, eight, who was the youngest victim to die in the attack alongside Martyn Hett, 29, Georgina Callander, 18, Olivia Campbell, 15; Off-duty police officer Elaine McIver, 43, John Atkinson, 26, Kelly Brewster, 32, Alison Lowe, 44, and friend Lisa Lees, 43.

Marcin Kils, 42, and Angelika Kils, 39, Nell Jones, 14, Jane Tweddle, 51, Michelle Kiss, 45, Sorrell Leczkowski, 14, Chloe Rutherford, 17, and Liam Curry, 19, Eilidh MacLeod, 14, Wendy Fawell, 50, Courtney Boyle, 19, and her stepdad Philip Tron, 32, and Megan Hurley, 15, was the final victim to be named.

Abedi, formerly of Tripoli, Libya, denies 22 counts of murder, one of attempted murder, and one of conspiring to cause explosions.
